status.full_text: @clekis B√∂ller sind f√ºr mich nicht Raketen und Font√§nen.

@g33konaut It was really amazing to see what you pulled off in 2017. 

I wonder what the reason for this was? Recruiting / Marketing for Archilogic? And would you say it returned what you invested?
@g33konaut How many of the conferences you went to did have 25% non white men in the panel?
@GinMon kennt ihr eigentlich auch √§hnliche Angebote aus Norwegen?

@Balgan @g33konaut It has so much to do with that! 
White dudes like me can easily afford travel costs, because we have well paid jobs. 
Check section 2. in this post: https://t.co/DjMY2PIj0d

You may read more on the topic at #paytospeak

@Balgan @g33konaut I know, you say: we don't receive submission from minorities, although we bend over backwards to aproach them.
What is the feedback from them, why they don't submit?

How to make people not lie in the workplace: 3 Goals for a great Workplace Culture
https://t.co/h7gcrTmbRA
This post received over 60 comments on HackerNews: https://t.co/3i9ljNdgYC - and many of them are detailed anecdotes on how lying is a very important part of our daily work. https://t.co/bJaLJ7yVhL
While nobody disagrees that this kind of culture would be worth striving for, the majority's opinion seems to be that it is impossible to achieve.

But we all share the desire for living/working in an environment like this and this gives me hope! Anybody who start the discussion  in their team or company about the way they interact, will quickly and most certainly find allies and can grow a team of change agents  from that.
Everyone culture ( https://t.co/uG3adYfl9Z)  was mentioned and I would also recommend books like Unboss   https://t.co/PkcIVpdwjl...  or Joy, Inc. https://t.co/w8HDDFLOYG.
@molily Great work, I'm really happy to see a very aproachable introduction to testing in it!

I am one of the 87 that joined Nordic in 2017, moving to Trondheim üá≥üá¥from Frankfurt üá©üá™ and it has been a brilliant experience! It's an awesome community of experts, where you will learn something new everyday, and will be building future standards of wireless communication. > https://t.co/ymNQV8oF5w

And don't get me started about how beautiful Norway is, check out  my posts on Instagram: https://t.co/wIDXJ0CJm2. I'm always happy to help if you have any  question regarding the work here or moving to Norway in general (Nordic  pays for that, of course), so DM me here.

For a brief time some npm packages could (and were) replaced by malicious users:
https://t.co/SyEcawx1v1 https://t.co/qYEOc0GuB3
Maybe it's time to put npm packages on ipfs.
This is a good reminder that npm's package-lock is very stable and will prevent attackers replacing packages in existing projects: https://t.co/8ihfgpdS0W https://t.co/IbBlooFtKd
@martinemmert Even a perfectly designed library would not have prevented an attacker replacing it, because of the way npm works right now.

@martinemmert You own your dependencies.
It's simple and sad like this.
@miskaknapek @mtchl Cool, and it's free!

So, quick poll on #JavaScript throw: should you always throw an instance of Error(), or is it ok to throw anything?

 I'm also happy to hear your reasoning for the choice.

You can `throw undefined`, btw.

I personally think you should always throw an Error instance. Technically this is superfluous, since everywhere you catch it, you know you have an error.

But: Errors have attached stack traces. So it's easier to debug.
@PiaOnTheMove @sipgate @Female_Finance wenn die @findingmarbles auch dabei ist ... unbedingt ansprechen!
@tdvorak Absolutely!

@RidingWolf The question here is: *If* you throw an error, what should the argument to throw be.

Don't throw as a rule sounds strange. Can you explain?

@RidingWolf For me the expressiveness of code by using exceptions outranks performance implications by a magnitude. 

Having good code will mean less bugs, faster time to market, which is in typical web app cases worth way more cash.

I just had a 2 hour talk with a company assisting in hiring and my #1 advise to them was:

@Morl99 Here are some ideas:
- go to (un-)conferences and talk about your work
- to there to hear others talk 
Doing that you build a network and create a more interesting image for your company than the marketing department can.

@Morl99 This works also for digital work, like being active in forums, projects. People get to know you, and when you share a job they will listen.
And you will learn about people that are looking for a job, and if you approach them you won't be a stranger.
